fields.field: contains any arbitrary component-level unit of text, acting as an anonymous container for phrase or inter level elements analogous to, but without the semantic baggage of, a paragraph.
contains an abbreviation of any sort.
contains a summary or formal abstract prefixed to an existing source document by the encoder.

contains details of any significant additional material which may be closely associated with the manuscript or object being described, such as non-contemporaneous documents or fragments bound in with it at some earlier historical period.
contains any descriptive or other information concerning the process by which a manuscript or manuscript part or other object entered the holding institution.
contains a brief informal description of what a participant in a language interaction is doing other than speaking, if anything.
contains the name of an actor appearing within a cast list.
contains letters, words, or phrases inserted in the source text by an author, scribe, or a previous annotator or corrector.
groups additional information, combining bibliographic information about a manuscript or other object, or surrogate copies of it, with curatorial or administrative information.
contains a description of any significant additions found within a manuscript or other object, such as marginalia or other annotations.
contains an additional name component, such as a nickname, epithet, or alias, or any other descriptive phrase used within a personal name.
contains a postal address, for example of a publisher, an organization, or an individual.
contains one line of a postal address.
marks the beginning of a longer sequence of text added by an author, scribe, annotator or corrector (see also add).
contains information about the present custody and availability of the manuscript or other object, and also about the record description itself.
contains an informal description of a person's present or past affiliation with some organization, for example an employer or sponsor.
specifies the age of a person.
identifies an alternation or a set of choices among elements or passages.
indicates that the constructs referenced by its children form an alternation
groups a collection of alt elements and possibly pointers.
supplies the recommended XML name for an element, class, attribute, etc. in some language.
contains an alternative or former structured identifier used for a manuscript or other object, such as a former catalogue number.
contains a sequence of letters or signs present in an abbreviation which are omitted or replaced in the expanded form of the abbreviation.
contains bibliographic elements describing an item (e.g. an article or poem) published within a monograph or journal and not as an independent publication.
attaches an identifier to a point within a text, whether or not it corresponds with a textual element.
groups together various annotations, e.g. for parallel interpretations of a spoken segment.
indicates the presence of any elements in a content model
contains one entry in a critical apparatus, with an optional lemma and usually one or more readings or notes on the relevant passage.
records information about an application which has edited the TEI file.
provides information about an application which has acted upon the document.
encodes an arc, the connection from one node to another in a graph.
contains a formal list or prose description of the topics addressed by a subdivision of a text.
provides attributes for elements representing speech or action that can be directed at a group or individual.
provides attributes for elements representing speech or action that can be ascribed to a specific individual.
provides an attribute to indicate whether or not the element concerned is considered to mark the end of an orthographic token in the same way as whitespace.
provides attributes which can be used to associate a representation such as a name or title with canonical information about the object being named or referenced.
provides attributes for specifying the specific part of a bibliographic item being cited.
provides attributes indicating how multiple references to the same object in a schema should be combined
provides attributes which can be used to position their parent element within a two dimensional coordinate system.
provides an attribute which may be used to supply a canonical reference as a means of identifying the target of a pointer.
provides attributes describing the nature of any physical damage affecting a reading.
provides attributes for normalization of elements that contain datable events to a custom dating system (i.e. other than the Gregorian used by W3 and ISO).
provides attributes for normalization of elements that contain datable events using the ISO 8601 standard.
provides attributes for normalization of elements that contain datable events conforming to the W3C XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition.
provides attributes for normalization of elements that contain dates, times, or datable events.

provides the dcr:datacat and dcr:ValueDatacat attributes which are used to align XML elements or attributes with the appropriate Data Categories (DCs) defined by the ISO 12620:2009 standard and stored in the Web repository called ISOCat at http://www.isocat.org/.
provides attributes for those elements in the TEI header which may be independently selected by means of the special purpose decls attribute.
provides attributes for elements which may be independently associated with a particular declarable element within the header, thus overriding the inherited default for that element.
provides attributes indicating how a deprecated feature will be treated in future releases.
provides attributes for describing the size of physical objects.
provides attributes common to all elements which behave in the same way as divisions.
provides attributes for use on metadata elements describing the status of a document.
provides attributes for recording normalized temporal durations.
provides attributes for recording normalized temporal durations.
provides attributes for normalization of elements that contain datable events.
provides attributes identifying the source edition from which some encoded feature derives.
provides attributes describing the nature of an encoded scholarly intervention or interpretation of any kind.
provides an attribute which may be used to indicate enjambement of the parent element.
provides an attribute used to distinguish different styles of dictionary entries.
provides an attribute for representing fragmentation of a structural element, typically as a consequence of some overlapping hierarchy.
provides additional global attributes for associating specific analyses or interpretations with appropriate portions of a text.
supplies the change attribute, allowing its member elements to specify one or more states or revision campaigns with which they are associated.
provides an attribute used to express correspondence between an element containing transcribed text and all or part of an image representing that text.
provides a set of attributes for hypertextual linking.
provides rendering attributes common to all elements in the TEI encoding scheme.
provides attributes indicating the agent responsible for some aspect of the text, the markup or something asserted by the markup, and the degree of certainty associated with it.
provides an attribute used by elements to point to an external source.
provides attributes common to all elements in the TEI encoding scheme.
provides attributes describing aspects of the hand in which a manuscript is written.
provides the identifying attribute for elements which can be subsequently referenced by means of a key attribute.
provides attributes for specifying the type of a computer resource using a standard taxonomy.
provides attributes for elements which represent a formal analysis or interpretation.
provides a set of attributes for specifying standard and normalized values, grammatical functions, alternate or equivalent forms, and information about composite parts.

field.name: att.linguistic
field.gloss: the token is not adjacent to another

fields.field: provides a set of attributes concerning linguistic features of tokens, for usage within token-level elements, specifically w and pc in the analysis module.
provides attributes to represent a regularized or normalized measurement.
provides attributes for specifying display and related properties of external media.
defines a set of attributes which certain elements may use to represent metrical information.
provides an attribute to indicate the type of section which is changing at a specific milestone.
provides an attribute to indicate text type or classification.
provides attributes used to describe excerpts from a manuscript placed in a description thereof.
provides an attribute indicating the target namespace for an object being created
provides attributes common to elements which refer to named persons, places, organizations etc.
provides an attribute to indicate any specialised notation used for element content.
provides attributes for describing the extent of lexical references for a dictionary term.
provides attributes for regular-expression matching and replacement.

field.name: att.personal
field.gloss: attributes for components of names usually, but not necessarily, personal names

fields.field: common attributes for those elements which form part of a name usually, but not necessarily, a personal name.
provides attributes for describing where on the source page or object a textual element appears.
provides a set of attributes common to all elements which enclose groups of pointer elements.
provides a set of attributes used by all elements which point to other elements by means of one or more URI references.
provides attributes which indicate the orthographic or pronunciation forms of the headword in a dictionary.
provides attributes for describing numerical ranges.
provides attributes to mark the beginning or ending of a fragmentary manuscript or other witness.
supplies attributes for the elements which define component parts of a content model.
provides attributes by which a resource (such as an externally held media file) may be located.
provides attributes for selecting particular elements within a document.
provides attributes for elements used for arbitrary segmentation.
provides attributes for elements in lists or groups that are sortable, but whose sorting key cannot be derived mechanically from the element content.
provides attributes for elements which delimit a span of text by pointing mechanisms rather than by enclosing it.
provides attributes to specify the name of a formal definition language used to provide formatting or rendition information.
provides attributes used to decorate rows or cells of a table.
defines a set of attributes common to all elements representing variant readings in text critical work.
provides attributes common to those elements which have a duration in time, expressed either absolutely or by reference to an alignment map.
provides attributes specific to elements encoding authorial or scribal intervention in a text when transcribing manuscript or similar sources.
provides attributes used to indicate the status of a translatable portion of an ODD document.
provides attributes which can be used to classify or subclassify elements in any way.
supplies the attribute used to identify the witnesses supporting a particular reading in a critical apparatus.
provides an attribute to indicate the hand in which the content of an element was written in the source being transcribed.
contains the name of an attribute appearing within running text.
contains the definition of a single attribute.
contains documentation for all the attributes associated with this element, as a series of attDef elements.
points to the definition of an attribute or group of attributes.
in a bibliographic reference, contains the name(s) of an author, personal or corporate, of a work; for example in the same form as that provided by a recognized bibliographic name authority.
supplies the name of a person or other agency responsible for making a work available, other than a publisher or distributor.
supplies information about the availability of a text, for example any restrictions on its use or distribution, its copyright status, any licence applying to it, etc.
contains any appendixes, etc. following the main part of a text.
contains a loosely-structured bibliographic citation of which the sub-components may or may not be explicitly tagged.
contains a fully-structured bibliographic citation, in which all components of the TEI file description are present.
defines the scope of a bibliographic reference, for example as a list of page numbers, or a named subdivision of a larger work.
contains a structured bibliographic citation, in which only bibliographic sub-elements appear and in a specified order.

defines a biconditional feature-structure constraint; both consequent and antecedent are specified as feature structures or groups of feature structures; the constraint is satisfied if both subsume a given feature structure, or if both do not.
represents the value part of a feature-value specification which can contain either of exactly two possible values.
provides encoded binary data representing an inline graphic, audio, video or other object.
contains a description of one binding, i.e. type of covering, boards, etc. applied to a manuscript or other object.
describes the present and former bindings of a manuscript or other object, either as a series of paragraphs or as a series of distinct binding elements, one for each binding of the manuscript.
contains information about a person's birth, such as its date and place.
contains the name of a geo-political unit consisting of two or more nation states or countries.
contains the whole body of a single unitary text, excluding any front or back matter.
describes a broadcast used as the source of a spoken text.
contains the primary statement of responsibility given for a work on its title page or at the head or end of the work.
represents a character.
marks the point at which a metrical line may be divided.
describes a calendar or dating system used in a dating formula in the text.
contains a description of the calendar system used in any dating expression found in the text.
describes a particular camera angle or viewpoint in a screen play.
contains the text of a caption or other text displayed as part of a film script or screenplay.
contains grammatical case information given by a dictionary for a given form.
groups one or more individual castItem elements within a cast list.
contains a single entry within a cast list, describing either a single role or a list of non-speaking roles.
contains a single cast list or dramatis personae.
describes the system used to ensure correct ordering of the quires or similar making up a codex, incunable, or other object typically by means of annotations at the foot of the page.
describes some category within a taxonomy or text typology, either in the form of a brief prose description or in terms of the situational parameters used by the TEI formal textDesc.
contains an individual descriptive category, possibly nested within a superordinate category, within a user-defined taxonomy.
specifies one or more defined categories within some taxonomy or text typology.
marks the beginning of a new column of a text on a multi-column page.
contains one cell of a table.
indicates the degree of certainty associated with some aspect of the text markup.
documents a change or set of changes made during the production of a source document, or during the revision of an electronic file.
describes the medium or channel by which a text is delivered or experienced. For a written text, this might be print, manuscript, email, etc.; for a spoken one, radio, telephone, face-to-face, etc.
provides descriptive information about a character.
provides information about nonstandard characters and glyphs.
contains the name of a character, expressed following Unicode conventions.
provides a name and value for some property of the parent character or glyph.
groups a number of alternative encodings for the same point in a text.

contains a quotation from some other document, together with a bibliographic reference to its source. In a dictionary it may contain an example text with at least one occurrence of the word form, used in the sense being described, or a translation of the headword, or an example.
defines the range of cited content, often represented by pages or other units
represents a grammatical clause.
contains the classification code used for this text in some standard classification system.
contains one or more taxonomies defining any classificatory codes used elsewhere in the text.
specifies all the classes of which the documented element or class is a member or subclass.
points to the specification for an attribute or model class which is to be included in a schema
contains reference information for a TEI element class; that is a group of elements which appear together in content models, or which share some common attribute, or both.
contains information about the physical climate of a place.
groups together salutations, datelines, and similar phrases appearing as a final group at the end of a division, especially of a letter.
contains literal code from some formal language such as a programming language.
contains a description of how the leaves, bifolia, or similar objects are physically arranged.
contains the name of a collection of manuscripts or other objects, not necessarily located within a single repository.
contains any sequence of words that co-occur with the headword with significant frequency.
contains the colophon of an item: that is, a statement providing information regarding the date, place, agency, or reason for production of the manuscript or other object.

defines a conditional feature-structure constraint; the consequent and the antecedent are specified as feature structures or feature-structure collections; the constraint is satisfied if both the antecedent and the consequent subsume a given feature structure, or if the antecedent does not.
contains a description of the physical condition of the manuscript or object.
describes the internal composition of a text or text sample, for example as fragmentary, complete, etc.
the formal rules of a constraint
contains a formal constraint, typically expressed in a rule-based schema language, to which a construct must conform in order to be considered valid
contains a declaration of the intended content model for the element (or other construct) being specified.
contains the correct form of a passage apparently erroneous in the copy text.
states how and under what circumstances corrections have been made in the text.
contains a structured description of the place, the name of a person/organization and the date related to the sending/receiving of a message or any other action related to the correspondence.
provides references to preceding or following correspondence related to this piece of correspondence.
contains a description of the actions related to one act of correspondence.
contains the name of a geo-political unit, such as a nation, country, colony, or commonwealth, larger than or administratively superior to a region and smaller than a bloc.
contains information about the creation of a text.
specifies an expression and replacement pattern for transforming a canonical reference into a URI.
describes a single event during the custodial history of a manuscript or other object.
contains a description of a manuscript or other object's custodial history, either as running prose or as a series of dated custodial events.
contains an area of damage to the text witness.
marks the beginning of a longer sequence of text which is damaged in some way but still legible.
Restricts the value of the strings used to represent values of a datatype, according to XML Schemas: Part 2: Datatypes.
identifies the datatype of an attribute value, either by referencing an item in an externally defined datatype library, or by pointing to a TEI-defined data specification
documents a datatype.
specifies the declared value for an attribute, by referring to any datatype defined by the chosen schema language.
contains a date in any format.
contains a brief description of the place, date, time, etc. of production of a letter, newspaper story, or other work, prefixed or suffixed to it as a kind of heading or trailer.
contains information about a person's death, such as its date and place.
contains a description of the decoration of a manuscript or other object, either as in paragraphs, or as one or more decoNote elements.
contains a note describing either a decorative component of a manuscript or other object, or a fairly homogenous class of such components.
contains definition text in a dictionary entry.
represents the value part of a feature-value specification which contains a defaulted value.
specifies the default declared value for an attribute.
contains a letter, word, or passage deleted, marked as deleted, or otherwise indicated as superfluous or spurious in the copy text by an author, scribe, or a previous annotator or corrector.
marks the beginning of a longer sequence of text deleted, marked as deleted, or otherwise signaled as superfluous or spurious by an author, scribe, annotator, or corrector.
contains a measurement measured across the spine of a book or codex, or (for other text-bearing objects) perpendicular to the measurement given by the width element.
describes the nature and extent of originality of this text.
contains a brief description of the object documented by its parent element, typically a documentation element or an entity.
encloses a part of a dictionary entry in which other phrase-level dictionary elements are freely combined.
contains any single measurement forming part of a dimensional specification of some sort.
contains a dimensional specification.
identifies any word or phrase which is regarded as linguistically distinct, for example as archaic, technical, dialectal, non-preferred, etc., or as forming part of a sublanguage.
supplies the name of a person or other agency responsible for the distribution of a text.
contains the name of any kind of subdivision of a settlement, such as a parish, ward, or other administrative or geographic unit.
contains a subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text.
contains a first-level subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text.
contains a second-level subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text.
contains a third-level subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text.
contains a fourth-level subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text.
contains a fifth-level subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text.
contains a sixth-level subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text.
contains the smallest possible subdivision of the front, body or back of a text, larger than a paragraph.
indicates the location at which a textual division generated automatically by a text-processing application is to appear.
contains the name of the author of the document, as given on the title page (often but not always contained in a byline).
contains the date of a document, as given on a title page or in a dateline.
contains an edition statement as presented on a title page of a document.
contains the imprint statement (place and date of publication, publisher name), as given (usually) at the foot of a title page.
contains the title of a document, including all its constituents, as given on a title page.
describes the most important social context in which the text was realized or for which it is intended, for example private vs. public, education, religion, etc.
describes the particularities of one edition of a text.
groups information relating to one edition of a text.

contains a secondary statement of responsibility for a bibliographic item, for example the name of an individual, institution or organization, (or of several such) acting as editor, compiler, translator, etc.
provides details of editorial principles and practices applied during the encoding of a text.
contains a description of the educational experience of a person.
contains any kind of illustrative example.
a single XML fragment demonstrating the use of some XML, such as elements, attributes, or processing instructions, etc., in which the egXML element functions as the root element.

field.name: eLeaf
field.gloss: leaf or terminal node of an embedding tree

fields.field: provides explicitly for a leaf of an embedding tree, which may also be encoded with the eTree element.
points to the specification for some element which is to be included in a schema
documents the structure, content, and purpose of a single element type.
contains an email address identifying a location to which email messages can be delivered.
marks words or phrases which are stressed or emphasized for linguistic or rhetorical effect.
indicates the presence of an empty node within a content model
documents the relationship between an electronic text and the source or sources from which it was derived.
contains a single structured entry in any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon.
contains a single unstructured entry in any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon.
contains a quotation, anonymous or attributed, appearing at the start or end of a section or on a title page.
contains the epilogue to a drama, typically spoken by an actor out of character, possibly in association with a particular performance or venue.
provides technical details of the equipment and media used for an audio or video recording used as the source for a spoken text.
specifies a component which is considered equivalent to the parent element, either by co-reference, or by external link.
provides an alternative to the tree element for representing ordered rooted tree structures.
encloses the etymological information in a dictionary entry.
contains data relating to any kind of significant event associated with a person, place, or organization.
contains a sequence of letters added by an editor or transcriber when expanding an abbreviation.
groups an example demonstrating the use of an element along with optional paragraphs of commentary.
contains the expansion of an abbreviation.
contains the explicit of a item, that is, the closing words of the text proper, exclusive of any rubric or colophon which might follow it.
describes the approximate size of a text stored on some carrier medium or of some other object, digital or non-digital, specified in any convenient units.
represents a feature value specification, that is, the association of a name with a value of any of several different types.
contains a representation of some written source in the form of a set of images rather than as transcribed or encoded text.
describes the extent to which the text may be regarded as imaginative or non-imaginative, that is, as describing a fictional or a non-fictional world.
specifies the faith, religion, or belief set of a person.
declares a single feature, specifying its name, organization, range of allowed values, and optionally its default value.
describes in prose what is represented by the feature being declared and its values.
contains a brief prose description of the appearance or content of a graphic figure, for use when documenting an image without displaying it.
groups elements representing or containing graphic information such as an illustration, formula, or figure.
contains a full bibliographic description of an electronic file.

contains information concerning the manuscript or other object's filiation, i.e. its relationship to other surviving manuscripts or other objects of the same text or contents, its protographs, antigraphs and apographs.

contains the string of words that denotes the end of a text division, often with an assertion as to its author and title, usually set off from the text itself by red ink, by a different size or type of script, or by some other such visual device.
assembles a library of f (feature) elements.
contains a single text of any kind, whether unitary or composite, which interrupts the text containing it at any point and after which the surrounding text resumes.
contains information about a person's period of activity.
describes the numbering system or systems used to count the leaves or pages in a codex or similar object.
identifies a word or phrase as belonging to some language other than that of the surrounding text.
contains a forename, given or baptismal name.
provides for groups of rooted trees.
groups all the information on the written and spoken forms of one headword.
contains a mathematical or other formula.
contains any prefatory matter (headers, abstracts, title page, prefaces, dedications, etc.) found at the start of a document, before the main body.
represents a feature structure, that is, a collection of feature-value pairs organized as a structural unit.
specifies constraints on the content of valid feature structures.
provides a feature system declaration comprising one or more feature structure declarations or feature structure declaration links.
declares one type of feature structure.
describes in prose what is represented by the type of feature structure declared in the enclosing fsDecl.
associates the name of a typed feature structure with a feature structure declaration for it.
specifies the name of an individual, institution, or organization responsible for the funding of a project or text.
assembles a library of reusable feature value elements (including complete feature structures).
contains a running head (e.g. a header, footer), catchword, or similar material appearing on the current page.
represents a glyph, or a non-standard character.

indicates a point where material has been omitted in a transcription, whether for editorial reasons described in the TEI header, as part of sampling practice, or because the material is illegible, invisible, or inaudible.
marks the beginning of a new gathering or quire in a transcribed codex.
identifies the morphological gender of a lexical item, as given in the dictionary.
contains a name component used to distinguish otherwise similar names on the basis of the relative ages or generations of the persons named.
contains any expression of a set of geographic coordinates, representing a point, line, or area on the surface of the earth in some notation.
documents the notation and the datum used for geographic coordinates expressed as content of the geo element elsewhere within the document.
contains a common noun identifying some geographical feature contained within a geographic name, such as valley, mount, etc.
identifies a name associated with some geographical feature such as Windrush Valley or Mount Sinai.
contains the name (generic identifier) of an element.
identifies a phrase or word used to provide a gloss or definition for some other word or phrase.
provides descriptive information about a character glyph.
contains the name of a glyph, expressed following Unicode conventions for character names.
within an entry in a dictionary or a terminological data file, contains grammatical information relating to a term, word, or form.
groups morpho-syntactic information about a lexical item, e.g. pos, gen, number, case, or iType (inflectional class).
encodes a graph, which is a collection of nodes, and arcs which connect the nodes.
indicates the location of a graphic or illustration, either forming part of a text, or providing an image of it.

contains the body of a composite text, grouping together a sequence of distinct texts (or groups of such texts) which are regarded as a unit for some purpose, for example the collected works of an author, a sequence of prose essays, etc.
contains a description of all the different hands used in a manuscript or other object.
describes a particular style or hand distinguished within a manuscript.
contains one or more handNote elements documenting the different hands identified within the source texts.
marks the beginning of a sequence of text written in a new hand, or the beginning of a scribal stint.
contains any type of heading, for example the title of a section, or the heading of a list, glossary, manuscript description, etc.
contains the heading for the item or gloss column in a glossary list or similar structured list.
contains the heading for the label or term column in a glossary list or similar structured list.
contains a measurement measured along the axis at right angles to the bottom of the written surface, i.e. parallel to the spine for a codex or book.
contains a heraldic formula or phrase, typically found as part of a blazon, coat of arms, etc.
marks a word or phrase as graphically distinct from the surrounding text, for reasons concerning which no claim is made.
groups elements describing the full history of a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object.
groups information relating to one homograph within an entry.
contains a hyphenated form of a dictionary headword, or hyphenation information in some other form.
summarizes the way in which hyphenation in a source text has been treated in an encoded version of it.

contains an identifier or name for an object of some kind in a formal language. ident is used for tokens such as variable names, class names, type names, function names etc. in formal programming languages.
supplies any form of identifier used to identify some object, such as a bibliographic item, a person, a title, an organization, etc. in a standardized way.
defines a conditional default value for a feature; the condition is specified as a feature structure, and is met if it subsumes the feature structure in the text for which a default value is sought.
separates the condition from the consequence in a bicond element.
contains a formal statement authorizing the publication of a work, sometimes required to appear on a title page or its verso.
groups information relating to the publication or distribution of a bibliographic item.
marks any phenomenon or occurrence, not necessarily vocalized or communicative, for example incidental noises or other events affecting communication.

contains the incipit of a manuscript or similar object item, that is the opening words of the text proper, exclusive of any rubric which might precede it, of sufficient length to identify the work uniquely; such incipits were, in former times, frequently used a means of reference to a work, in place of a title.
marks a location to be indexed for whatever purpose.
represents an intermediate (or internal) node of a tree.
contains the name of an organization such as a university or library, with which a manuscript or other object is identified, generally its holding institution.
describes the extent, cardinality and nature of any interaction among those producing and experiencing the text, for example in the form of response or interjection, commentary, etc.
summarizes a specific interpretative annotation which can be linked to a span of text.
collects together a set of related interpretations which share responsibility or type.
describes the scope of any analytic or interpretive information added to the text in addition to the transcription.
contains one component of a list.
indicates the inflectional class associated with a lexical item.
identifies a possibly fragmented segment of text, by pointing at the possibly discontiguous elements which compose it.
groups a collection of join elements and possibly pointers.
contains a list of keywords or phrases identifying the topic or nature of a text.
marks any communicative phenomenon, not necessarily vocalized, for example a gesture, frown, etc.
contains a single, possibly incomplete, line of verse.
contains any label or heading used to identify part of a text, typically but not exclusively in a list or glossary.
indicates the end of a lacuna in a mostly complete textual witness.
indicates the beginning of a lacuna in the text of a mostly complete textual witness.
contains the name of a language mentioned in etymological or other linguistic discussion.
summarizes the state of a person's linguistic knowledge, either as prose or by a list of langKnown elements.
summarizes the state of a person's linguistic competence, i.e., knowledge of a single language.
characterizes a single language or sublanguage used within a text.
describes the languages, sublanguages, registers, dialects, etc. represented within a text.
describes how text is laid out on the page or surface of the object, including information about any ruling, pricking, or other evidence of page-preparation techniques.
collects the set of layout descriptions applicable to a manuscript or other object.
marks the beginning of a new (typographic) line in some edition or version of a text.
contains a label for a form, example, translation, or other piece of information, e.g. abbreviation for, contraction of, literally, approximately, synonyms:, etc.
encodes the leaves (terminal nodes) of a tree.
contains the lemma, or base text, of a textual variation.
contains one or more verse lines functioning as a formal unit, e.g. a stanza, refrain, verse paragraph, etc.
contains information about a licence or other legal agreement applicable to the text.
contains the transcription of a topographic line in the source document
defines an association or hypertextual link among elements or passages, of some type not more precisely specifiable by other elements.
defines a collection of associations or hypertextual links.
contains any sequence of items organized as a list.
contains a list of apparatus entries.
contains a list of bibliographic citations of any kind.
groups a number of change descriptions associated with either the creation of a source text or the revision of an encoded text.
contains a list of descriptions, each of which provides information about an identifiable event.
provides for lists of forests.
contains a list of nyms, that is, standardized names for any thing.
contains a list of descriptions, each of which provides information about an identifiable physical object.
contains a list of elements, each of which provides information about an identifiable organization.

contains a list of descriptions, each of which provides information about an identifiable person or a group of people, for example the participants in a language interaction, or the people referred to in a historical source.
contains a list of places, optionally followed by a list of relationships (other than containment) defined amongst them.
contains a list of definitions of prefixing schemes used in data.pointer values, showing how abbreviated URIs using each scheme may be expanded into full URIs.
supplies a list of significant references to places where this element is discussed, in the current document or elsewhere.
provides information about relationships identified amongst people, places, and organizations, either informally as prose or as formally expressed relation links.
contains a list of various kinds of characteristics of people, places, and organizations.
supplies a list of transpositions, each of which is indicated at some point in a document typically by means of metamarks.
lists definitions for all the witnesses referred to by a critical apparatus, optionally grouped hierarchically.
contains a brief informal description of the kind of place concerned, for example: a room, a restaurant, a park bench, etc.
contains a locally defined name for some property.
defines the location of a place as a set of geographical coordinates, in terms of other named geo-political entities, or as an address.
defines a location within a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object typically as a (possibly discontinuous) sequence of folio references.
groups a number of locations which together form a distinct but discontinuous item within a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object.
represents a grammatical morpheme.
defines the content of prose elements that are not used for transcription of extant materials.
defines the content of paragraphs and similar elements.
defines a sequence of character data and those phrase-level elements that are not typically used for transcribing extant documents.
defines a sequence of character data and phrase-level elements.

defines the content model of elements such as notes or list items, which either contain a series of component-level elements or else have the same structure as a paragraph, containing a series of phrase-level and inter-level elements.
defines a sequence of character data and gaiji elements.
points to the specification for some pattern which is to be included in a schema
documents the function and implementation of a pattern.
contains one or more characters which are related to the parent character or glyph in some respect, as specified by the type attribute.
contains a word or phrase describing the material of which the object being described is composed.
contains a word or phrase referring to some quantity of an object or commodity, usually comprising a number, a unit, and a commodity name.
contains a group of dimensional specifications which relate to the same object, for example the height and width of a manuscript page.
indicates the location of any form of external media such as an audio or video clip etc.

contains the formalized descriptive title for a meeting or conference, for use in a bibliographic description for an item derived from such a meeting, or as a heading or preamble to publications emanating from it.
specifies class membership of the documented element or class.
marks words or phrases mentioned, not used.

contains or describes any kind of graphic or written signal within a document the function of which is to determine how it should be read rather than forming part of the actual content of the document.

documents the notation employed to represent a metrical pattern when this is specified as the value of a met, real, or rhyme attribute on any structural element of a metrical text (e.g. lg, l, or seg).
documents the intended significance of a particular character or character sequence within a metrical notation, either explicitly or in terms of other metSym elements in the same metDecl.

marks a boundary point separating any kind of section of a text, typically but not necessarily indicating a point at which some part of a standard reference system changes, where the change is not represented by a structural element.
represents any kind of modification identified within a single document.
groups elements used to represent a postal or email address.
groups elements such as names or postal codes which may appear as part of a postal address.
groups elements used to record application-specific information about a document in its header.
groups elements such as licences and paragraphs of text which may appear as part of an availability statement
groups elements containing a bibliographic description.
groups elements which represent components of a bibliographic description.
groups component elements of an entry in a cast list, such as dramatic role or actor's name.
groups component elements of the TEI header Category Description.
groups elements which are used to indicate uncertainty or precision of other elements.
groups elements (other than choice itself) which can be used within a choice alternation.
groups common chunk- and inter-level elements.
groups elements which may appear as part of the content element.
groups elements which define the parts (usually names, dates and places) of one action related to the correspondence.
groups elements which may appear as part of the correspContext element
groups together metadata elements for describing correspondence
groups elements containing temporal expressions.
groups elements which contain a description of their function.
groups elements which describe a measurement forming part of the physical dimensions of some object.
groups top-level structural divisions.
groups second-level structural divisions.
groups third-level structural divisions.
groups fourth-level structural divisions.
groups fifth-level structural divisions.
groups sixth-level structural divisions.
groups seventh-level structural divisions.
groups elements appearing at the end of a text division.
groups elements which can occur only at the end of a text division.
groups elements used to represent a structural division which is generated rather than explicitly present in the source.
groups elements used to represent un-numbered generic structural divisions.
groups elements structurally analogous to paragraphs within spoken texts.
groups paragraph-level elements appearing directly within divisions.
groups elements appearing at the beginning of a text division.
groups elements which can occur only at the beginning of a text division.
groups elements which can appear at either top or bottom of a textual division.
groups elements which may be used inside editorialDecl and appear multiple times.
groups elements containing examples or illustrations.
groups phrase-level elements which are typographically distinct and to which a specific function can be attributed.
groups elements which may be used inside encodingDesc and appear multiple times.
groups elements structurally analogous to paragraphs within dictionaries.
groups high level elements within a structured dictionary entry
groups non-morphological elements appearing within a dictionary entry.
groups elements which describe events.
groups elements which express complex feature values in feature structures.
group elements used to represent atomic feature values in feature structures.
groups elements which represent feature values in feature structures.
groups elements allowed within a form element in a dictionary.
groups elements which appear at the level of divisions within front or back matter of performance texts only.
groups elements which appear at the level of divisions within front or back matter.
groups elements used to represent individual non-Unicode characters or glyphs.
groups globally available elements which perform a specifically editorial function.
groups globally available elements which describe the status of other elements.
groups elements which may appear globally within spoken texts.
groups elements which may appear at any point within a TEI text.
groups elements which provide an alternative name, explanation, or description for any markup construct.
groups elements allowed within a gramGrp element in a dictionary.
groups elements containing images, formulae, and similar objects.
groups elements which may be used to describe individual hands distinguished within a manuscript.
groups elements used to provide a title or heading at the start of a text division.
groups phrase-level elements which are typographically distinct.
groups phrase-level elements which are typographically distinct but to which no specific function can be attributed.
groups the bibliographic elements which occur inside imprints.
groups elements which can appear either within or between paragraph-like elements.
groups elements used to gloss or explain other parts of a document.
elements adding further precision to the lexico-grammatical information provided for a dictionary entry.
groups phrase-level elements excluding those elements primarily intended for transcription of existing sources.
groups transcriptional elements which appear within lines or zones of a source-oriented transcription within a sourceDoc element.
groups list-like elements.
groups elements representing metrical components such as verse lines.
groups phrase-level elements which may appear within verse only.
groups elements which denote a number, a quantity, a measurement, or similar piece of text that conveys some numerical meaning.
groups milestone-style elements used to represent reference systems.
groups elements which provide morphological information within a dictionary entry.
groups elements which can appear within a manuscript item description.
groups elements which represent passages such as titles quoted from a manuscript as a part of its description.
groups elements which contain names of individuals or corporate bodies.
groups elements which name or refer to a person, place, or organization.
groups globally-available note-like elements.
groups elements which describe objects.
groups elements which generate declarations in some markup language in ODD documents.
groups elements which reference declarations in some markup language in ODD documents.
groups elements which can appear only as part of a place name.
groups elements which form part of the description of an organization.
groups elements describing changeable characteristics of an organization which have a definite duration.
groups elements describing specific events in a person's history, for example birth, marriage, or appointment.
groups elements which form part of a personal name.
groups elements which provide information about people and their relationships.
groups elements which form part of the description of a person.
groups elements describing changeable characteristics of a person which have a definite duration, for example occupation, residence, or name.
groups elements which can occur at the level of individual words or phrases.
groups phrase-level elements used to encode XML constructs such as element names, attribute names, and attribute values
groups specialized elements forming part of the physical description of a manuscript or similar written source.
groups elements which describe events at or affecting a place.
groups elements used to provide information about places and their relationships.
groups elements which form part of a place name.
groups elements which describe changing states of a place.
groups paragraph-like elements which can occur as direct constituents of front matter.
groups paragraph-like elements.
groups phrase-level elements containing names, dates, numbers, measures, and similar data.
groups phrase-level elements for simple editorial correction and transcription.
groups phrase-level elements for simple editorial interventions that may be useful both in transcribing and in authoring.
groups phrase-level elements used in manuscript description.
groups phrase-level elements used for editorial transcription of pre-existing source materials.
groups elements which may be used inside profileDesc and appear multiple times.
groups elements used for purposes of location of particular orthographic or pronunciation forms within a dictionary entry.
groups elements used for purposes of location and reference.
groups the child elements of a publicationStmt element of the TEI header that indicate an authorising agent.
groups the agency-specific child elements of the publicationStmt element of the TEI header.
groups elements related to highlighting which can appear either within or between chunk-level elements.
groups elements used to directly contain quotations.
groups elements which contain a single reading, other than the lemma, within a textual variation.
groups elements which mark the beginning or ending of a fragmentary manuscript or other witness.
groups elements used to describe details of an audio or video recording.
groups separate elements which constitute the content of a digital resource, as opposed to its metadata.
groups elements which are used to indicate intellectual or other significant responsibility, for example within a bibliographic element.
groups elements used for arbitrary segmentation.
groups elements used to describe the setting of a linguistic interaction.
groups elements which may be used inside sourceDesc and appear multiple times.
groups elements for referring to specification elements.
groups elements containing stage directions or similar things defined by the module for performance texts.
groups high level elements which may appear more than once in a TEI header.
groups elements used to categorize a text for example in terms of its situational parameters.
groups elements which can occur as direct constituents of a title page, such as docTitle, docAuthor, docImprint, or epigraph.
describes the processing intended for a specified element.
any grouping of model or modelSequence elements with a common output method
any sequence of model or modelSequence elements which is to be processed as a single set of actions
references a module which is to be incorporated into a schema.
documents the structure, content, and purpose of a single module, i.e. a named and externally visible group of declarations.
contains bibliographic elements describing an item (e.g. a book or journal) published as an independent item (i.e. as a separate physical object).
contains information about the grammatical mood of verbs (e.g. indicative, subjunctive, imperative).
marks the actual movement of one or more characters.
describes the intellectual content of a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object either as a series of paragraphs or as a series of structured manuscript items.
contains a description of a single identifiable manuscript or other text-bearing object.
contains information about a fragment of a scattered manuscript now held as a single unit or bound into a larger manuscript.
contains the information required to identify the manuscript or similar object being described.
describes an individual work or item within the intellectual content of a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object.
contains a structured description for an individual work or item within the intellectual content of a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object.
contains any form of unstructured alternative name used for a manuscript or other object, such as an ocellus nominum, or nickname.
contains information about an originally distinct manuscript or part of a manuscript, which is now part of a composite manuscript.
contains description of type of musical notation.
contains a proper noun or noun phrase.
contains a connecting phrase or link used within a name but not regarded as part of it, such as van der or of.
supplies the formal name of the namespace to which the elements documented by its children belong.
contains an informal description of a person's present or past nationality or citizenship.
encodes a node, a possibly labeled point in a graph.
indicates the extent of normalization or regularization of the original source carried out in converting it to electronic form.
encodes the presence of music notation in a text
contains a note or annotation.
collects together any notes providing information about a text additional to that recorded in other parts of the bibliographic description.
contains a number, written in any form.
indicates grammatical number associated with a form, as given in a dictionary.
represents the value part of a feature-value specification which contains a numeric value or range.
contains the definition for a canonical name or name component of any kind.
contains a description of a single identifiable physical object.
contains a description of the physical components making up the object which is being described.
groups one or more identifiers or pieces of locating information concerning a single object.
contains a proper noun or noun phrase used to refer to an object.
contains a word or phrase describing the type of object being referred to.
contains an informal description of a person's trade, profession or occupation.
marks that part of a relative temporal or spatial expression which indicates the direction of the offset between the two place names, dates, or times involved in the expression.
groups together dateline, byline, salutation, and similar phrases appearing as a preliminary group at the start of a division, especially of a letter.
in a dictionary example, indicates a reference to the orthographic form(s) of the headword.
provides information about an identifiable organization such as a business, a tribe, or any other grouping of people.
contains an organizational name.
contains a reading which is marked as following the original, rather than being normalized or corrected.
contains any form of date, used to identify the date of origin for a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object.
contains any descriptive or other information concerning the origin of a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object.
contains any form of place name, used to identify the place of origin for a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object.
gives the orthographic form of a dictionary headword.
describes the rendering or appearance intended for all occurrences of an element in a specified context for a specified type of output.
marks paragraphs in prose.
provides a parameter for a model behaviour by supplying its name and an XPath expression identifying the location of its content.
list of parameter specifications
supplies specification for one parameter of a model behaviour
describes the identifiable speakers, voices, or other participants in any kind of text or other persons named or otherwise referred to in a text, edition, or metadata.
defines any line passing through two or more points within a surface element.
marks a pause either between or within utterances.
marks the beginning of a new page in a paginated document.
contains a character or string of characters regarded as constituting a single punctuation mark.
contains an indication of the grammatical person (1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.) associated with a given inflected form in a dictionary.
contains a section of front or back matter describing how a dramatic piece is to be performed in general or how it was performed on some specific occasion.
contains a proper noun or proper-noun phrase referring to a person, possibly including one or more of the person's forenames, surnames, honorifics, added names, etc.
provides information about an identifiable individual, for example a participant in a language interaction, or a person referred to in a historical source.
provides information about one of the personalities identified for a given individual, where an individual has multiple personalities.
describes a group of individuals treated as a single person for analytic purposes.
represents a grammatical phrase.
contains a full physical description of a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object optionally subdivided using more specialized elements from the model.physDescPart class.
contains data about a geographic location
contains an absolute or relative place name.
contains information about the population of a place.
indicates the part of speech assigned to a dictionary headword such as noun, verb, or adjective.

field.name: postBox
field.gloss: postal box or post office box

fields.field: contains a number or other identifier for some postal delivery point other than a street address.
contains a numerical or alphanumeric code used as part of a postal address to simplify sorting or delivery of mail.
contains a postscript, e.g. to a letter.
indicates the numerical accuracy or precision associated with some aspect of the text markup.
in a dictionary example, indicates a reference to the pronunciation(s) of the headword.
defines a prefixing scheme used in data.pointer values, showing how abbreviated URIs using the scheme may be expanded into full URIs.
describes the extent to which a text may be regarded as prepared or spontaneous.
supplies the name of the principal researcher responsible for the creation of an electronic text.
provides a detailed description of non-bibliographic aspects of a text, specifically the languages and sublanguages used, the situation in which it was produced, the participants and their setting.
describes in detail the aim or purpose for which an electronic file was encoded, together with any other relevant information concerning the process by which it was assembled or collected.
contains the prologue to a drama, typically spoken by an actor out of character, possibly in association with a particular performance or venue.
contains the pronunciation(s) of the word.

contains any descriptive or other information concerning a single identifiable episode during the history of a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object after its creation but before its acquisition.
defines a pointer to another location.
groups information concerning the publication or distribution of an electronic or other text.
provides the name of the organization responsible for the publication or distribution of a bibliographic item.
contains the name of the place where a bibliographic item was published.
specifies editorial practice adopted with respect to punctuation marks in the original.
characterizes a single purpose or communicative function of the text.

contains material which is distinguished from the surrounding text using quotation marks or a similar method, for any one of a variety of reasons including, but not limited to: direct speech or thought, technical terms or jargon, authorial distance, quotations from elsewhere, and passages that are mentioned but not used.
specifies editorial practice adopted with respect to quotation marks in the original.
contains a phrase or passage attributed by the narrator or author to some agency external to the text.
contains a single reading within a textual variation.
within a textual variation, groups two or more readings perceived to have a genetic relationship or other affinity.
contains a dictionary entry for a lexical item related to the headword, such as a compound phrase or derived form, embedded inside a larger entry.
provides information about the source and revision status of the parent manuscript or object description itself.
provides details of an audio or video recording event used as the source of a spoken text, either directly or from a public broadcast.
describes a set of recordings used as the basis for transcription of a spoken text.
indicates one or more cancelled interventions in a document which have subsequently been marked as reaffirmed or repeated.
defines a reference to another location, possibly modified by additional text or comment.
specifies how canonical references are constructed for this text.
specifies one component of a canonical reference defined by the milestone method.
contains a reading which has been regularized or normalized in some sense.
contains the name of an administrative unit such as a state, province, or county, larger than a settlement, but smaller than a country.
contains or references some other bibliographic item which is related to the present one in some specified manner, for example as a constituent or alternative version of it.
describes any kind of relationship or linkage amongst a specified group of places, events, persons, objects or other items.
contains any commentary or discussion about the usage of an element, attribute, class, or entity not otherwise documented within the containing element.
supplies information about the rendition or appearance of one or more elements in the source text.
contains the name of a repository within which manuscripts or other objects are stored, possibly forming part of an institution.
describes a person's present or past places of residence.
contains a phrase describing the nature of a person's intellectual responsibility, or an organization's role in the production or distribution of a work.
identifies the individual(s) responsible for some aspect of the content or markup of particular element(s).

supplies a statement of responsibility for the intellectual content of a text, edition, recording, or series, where the specialized elements for authors, editors, etc. do not suffice or do not apply. May also be used to encode information about individuals or organizations which have played a role in the production or distribution of a bibliographic work.
indicates restoration of text to an earlier state by cancellation of an editorial or authorial marking or instruction.
contains a sequence of writing which has been retraced, for example by over-inking, to clarify or fix it.
summarizes the revision history for a file.
marks the rhyming part of a metrical line.
contains the name of a dramatic role, as given in a cast list.
describes a character's role in a drama.
contains a name component which indicates that the referent has a particular role or position in society, such as an official title or rank.
represents the root node of a tree.
contains one row of a table.
contains a general purpose name or referring string.

contains the text of any rubric or heading attached to a particular manuscript item, that is, a string of words through which a manuscript or other object signals the beginning of a text division, often with an assertion as to its author and title, which is in some way set off from the text itself, typically in red ink, or by use of different size or type of script, or some other such visual device.
contains a sentence-like division of a text.
indicates passages thought or spoken aloud, whether explicitly indicated in the source or not, whether directly or indirectly reported, whether by real people or fictional characters.
contains a salutation or greeting prefixed to a foreword, dedicatory epistle, or other division of a text, or the salutation in the closing of a letter, preface, etc.
contains a prose description of the rationale and methods used in sampling texts in the creation of a corpus or collection.
describes or points to a related customization or schema file
generates a TEI-conformant schema and documentation for it.
contains a description of the scripts used in a manuscript or other object.
describes a particular script distinguished within the description of a manuscript or similar resource.
contains a citation giving details of the script used for a spoken text.
contains a description of one seal or similar applied to the object described
describes the seals or similar items related to the object described, either as a series of paragraphs or as a series of seal elements.
marks the word or words taken from a fixed point in a codex (typically the beginning of the second leaf) in order to provide a unique identifier for it.
Secluded. Marks text present in the source which the editor believes to be genuine but out of its original place (which is unknown).
represents any segmentation of text below the chunk level.
describes the principles according to which the text has been segmented, for example into sentences, tone-units, graphemic strata, etc.
groups together all information relating to one word sense in a dictionary entry, for example definitions, examples, and translation equivalents.
indicates that the constructs referenced by its children form a sequence
contains information about the series in which a book or other bibliographic item has appeared.
groups information about the series, if any, to which a publication belongs.
contains a description of the setting, time, locale, appearance, etc., of the action of a play, typically found in the front matter of a printed performance text (not a stage direction).
describes one particular setting in which a language interaction takes place.
describes the setting or settings within which a language interaction takes place, or other places otherwise referred to in a text, edition, or metadata.
contains the name of a settlement such as a city, town, or village identified as a single geo-political or administrative unit.
specifies the sex of a person.
marks the point at which some paralinguistic feature of a series of utterances by any one speaker changes.
contains text reproduced although apparently incorrect or inaccurate.
contains discussion of the leaf or quire signatures found within a codex or similar object.
contains the closing salutation, etc., appended to a foreword, dedicatory epistle, or other division of a text.
contains a word or phrase for which the author or narrator indicates a disclaiming of responsibility, for example by the use of scare quotes or italics.
contains an informal description of a person's perceived social or economic status.
describes a sound effect or musical sequence specified within a screen play or radio script.
describes the original source for the information contained with a manuscript or object description.

describes the source from which an electronic text was derived or generated, typically a bibliographic description in the case of a digitized text, or a phrase such as "born digital" for a text which has no previous existence.
contains a transcription or other representation of a single source document potentially forming part of a dossier gntique or collection of sources.
contains an individual speech in a performance text, or a passage presented as such in a prose or verse text.
indicates the location of a significant space in the text.
associates an interpretative annotation directly with a span of text.
collects together span tags.
contains a specialized form of heading or label, giving the name of one or more speakers in a dramatic text or fragment.
indicates that a description of the specified element or class should be included at this point within a document.
contains any convenient grouping of specifications for use within the current module.
indicates that the declarations contained by the specGrp referenced should be inserted at this point.
marks where a list of descriptions is to be inserted into the prose documentation.
contains a group of speeches or songs in a performance text presented in a source as constituting a single unit or number.
specifies the name of a sponsoring organization or institution.
contains any kind of stage direction within a dramatic text or fragment.
contains a word or phrase describing a stamp or similar device.
contains a description of some status or quality attributed to a person, place, or organization often at some specific time or for a specific date range.
specifies the format used when standardized date or number values are supplied.
contains a full street address including any name or number identifying a building as well as the name of the street or route on which it is located.
contains the stress pattern for a dictionary headword, if given separately.
represents the value part of a feature-value specification which contains a string.
specifies the name of the formal language in which style or renditional information is supplied elsewhere in the document. The specific version of the scheme may also be supplied.
contains subcategorization information (transitive/intransitive, countable/non-countable, etc.)
groups one or more deletions with one or more additions when the combination is to be regarded as a single intervention in the text.
identifies a series of possibly fragmented additions, deletions or other revisions on a manuscript that combine to make up a single intervention in the text

contains an overview of the available information concerning some aspect of an item or object (for example, its intellectual content, history, layout, typography etc.) as a complement or alternative to the more detailed information carried by more specific elements.
groups a sequence of entries within any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon which function as a single unit, for example a set of homographs.
signifies text supplied by the transcriber or editor for any reason; for example because the original cannot be read due to physical damage, or because of an obvious omission by the author or scribe.
contains a description of the materials etc. which make up the physical support for the written part of a manuscript or other object.
groups elements describing the physical support for the written part of a manuscript or other object.

defines a written surface as a two-dimensional coordinate space, optionally grouping one or more graphic representations of that space, zones of interest within that space, and transcriptions of the writing within them.
defines any kind of useful grouping of written surfaces, for example the recto and verso of a single leaf, which the encoder wishes to treat as a single unit.
contains a family (inherited) name, as opposed to a given, baptismal, or nick name.
marks text present in the source which the editor believes to be superfluous or redundant.
contains information about any representations of the manuscript or other object being described which may exist in the holding institution or elsewhere.
contains the syllabification of the headword.
represents the value part of a feature-value specification which contains one of a finite list of symbols.
contains text displayed in tabular form, in rows and columns.
contains text of a complete start- or end-tag, possibly including attribute specifications, but excluding the opening and closing markup delimiter characters.
provides detailed information about the tagging applied to a document.
documents the usage of a specific element within a specified document.
defines a typology either implicitly, by means of a bibliographic citation, or explicitly by a structured taxonomy.
describes a special-purpose stage direction that is not meant for the actors.
contains a single TEI-conformant document, combining a single TEI header with one or more members of the model.resourceLike class. Multiple TEI elements may be combined to form a teiCorpus element.
contains the whole of a TEI encoded corpus, comprising a single corpus header and one or more TEI elements, each containing a single text header and a text.
defines the range of attribute values expressing a degree of certainty.
defines the range of attribute values used for a non-negative integer value used as a count.
defines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using ISO 8601 standard formats
defines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using W3C datatypes.
defines the range of attribute values expressed as a single XML name taken from a list of documented possibilities.
defines attribute values used to express an interval value.
defines the range of attribute values expressing a coded value by means of an arbitrary identifier, typically taken from a set of externally-defined possibilities.
defines the range of attribute values used to identify a particular combination of human language and writing system.
defines the range of attribute values expressed as an XML Name.
defines the range of attribute values used to indicate XML namespaces as defined by the W3C Namespaces in XML Technical Recommendation.
defines attribute values which contain either an absolute namespace URI or a qualified XML name.
defines attribute values which contain either the null string or an XML name.
defines the range of attribute values used for numeric values.
defines a range of values for use in specifying the size of an object that is intended for display.
defines attribute values which are expressed as a regular expression.
defines the data type used to express a point in cartesian space.
defines the range of attribute values used to provide a single URI, absolute or relative, pointing to some other resource, either within the current document or elsewhere.
defines a range of values that may function as a URI scheme name.
defines the range of attribute values expressing a probability.
defines a range of attribute values which can be expressed either as a numeric probability or as a coded certainty value.
defines attribute values which contain a replacement template.
defines the range of attribute values used to identify human or animal sex.

defines the range of attribute values expressing a temporal expression such as a date, a time, or a combination of them, that conform to the international standard Data elements and interchange formats Information interchange Representation of dates and times.

defines the range of attribute values expressing a temporal expression such as a date, a time, or a combination of them, that conform to the W3C XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition specification.
defines the range of attribute values used to express some kind of identifying string as a single sequence of unicode characters possibly including whitespace.
defines the range of attribute values used to express a truth value.
defines an attribute value which can be either any non-negative integer or the string "unbounded".
defines the range of attribute values which may be used to specify a TEI or Unicode version number.
defines the range of attribute values used for version numbers.
defines the range of attribute values expressed as a single word or token.
defines attribute values which contain an XML name.
defines attribute values which contain an XPath expression.
defines the range of attribute values used to express a truth value which may be unknown.
supplies descriptive and declarative metadata associated with a digital resource or set of resources.
contains a single-word, multi-word, or symbolic designation which is regarded as a technical term.
contains information about the physical terrain of a place.
contains a single text of any kind, whether unitary or composite, for example a poem or drama, a collection of essays, a novel, a dictionary, or a corpus sample.
groups information which describes the nature or topic of a text in terms of a standard classification scheme, thesaurus, etc.
provides a description of a text in terms of its situational parameters.
describes the languages and writing systems identified within the bibliographic work being described, rather than its description.
indicates the presence of a text node in a content model
separates the condition from the default in an if, or the antecedent and the consequent in a cond element.
contains a phrase defining a time of day in any format.
provides a set of ordered points in time which can be linked to elements of a spoken text to create a temporal alignment of that text.
contains a title for any kind of work.
contains the title page of a text, appearing within the front or back matter.
contains a subsection or division of the title of a work, as indicated on a title page.
groups information about the title of a work and those responsible for its content.
indicates the grammatical tense associated with a given inflected form in a dictionary.
contains a closing title or footer appearing at the end of a division of a text.

contains a description of some status or quality attributed to a person, place, or organization typically, but not necessarily, independent of the volition or action of the holder and usually not at some specific time or for a specific date range.
describes the set of transcription conventions used, particularly for spoken material.
describes a single textual transposition as an ordered list of at least two pointers specifying the order in which the elements indicated should be re-combined.
encodes a tree, which is made up of a root, internal nodes, leaves, and arcs from root to leaves.
provides for an underspecified eTree, that is, an eTree with information left out.
contains a description of the typefaces or other aspects of the printing of an incunable or other printed source.
describes a particular font or other significant typographic feature distinguished within the description of a printed resource.
contains a stretch of speech usually preceded and followed by silence or by a change of speaker.
contains a word, phrase, or passage which cannot be transcribed with certainty because it is illegible or inaudible in the source.
indicates one or more marked-up interventions in a document which have subsequently been marked for cancellation.
contains the name of a registered Unicode normative or informative property.
contains a symbol, a word or a phrase referring to a unit of measurement in any kind of formal or informal system.
contains usage information in a dictionary entry.
contains a single attribute value.
specifies any semantic or syntactic constraint on the value that an attribute may take, additional to the information carried by the datatype element.
documents a single value in a predefined list of values.
contains one or more valItem elements defining possible values.
represents the value part of a feature-value specification which contains a set of values, only one of which can be valid.
contains a single value for some property, attribute, or other analysis.
declares the method used to encode text-critical variants.
represents the value part of a feature-value specification which contains multiple values organized as a set, bag, or list.

declares the default value to be supplied when a feature structure does not contain an instance of f for this name; if unconditional, it is specified as one (or, depending on the value of the org attribute of the enclosing fDecl) more fs elements or primitive values; if conditional, it is specified as one or more if elements; if no default is specified, or no condition matches, the value none is assumed.
describes the visual context of some part of a screen play in terms of what the spectator sees, generally independent of any dialogue.
represents the value part of a feature-value specification which appears at more than one point in a feature structure.
represents a feature value which is the result of merging together the feature values contained by its children, using the organization specified by the org attribute.
represents a feature value which is the negation of its content.
marks any vocalized but not necessarily lexical phenomenon, for example voiced pauses, non-lexical backchannels, etc.

defines the range of allowed values for a feature, in the form of an fs, vAlt, or primitive value; for the value of an f to be valid, it must be subsumed by the specified range; if the f contains multiple values (as sanctioned by the org attribute), then each value must be subsumed by the vRange.
represents a grammatical (not necessarily orthographic) word.
contains a word or phrase describing a watermark or similar device.
indicates a point in time either relative to other elements in the same timeline tag, or absolutely.
contains a measurement measured along the axis parallel to the bottom of the written surface, i.e. perpendicular to the spine of a book or codex.
contains a list of one or more sigla of witnesses attesting a given reading, in a textual variation.
gives further information about a particular witness, or witnesses, to a particular reading.
indicates the end, or suspension, of the text of a fragmentary witness.
contains either a description of a single witness referred to within the critical apparatus, or a list of witnesses which is to be referred to by a single sigil.
indicates the beginning, or resumption, of the text of a fragmentary witness.
contains a passage of written text revealed to participants in the course of a spoken text.
provides a container element into which metadata in non-TEI formats may be placed.
contains a phrase, sentence, or icon referring the reader to some other location in this or another text.
defines any two-dimensional area within a surface element.
